title: Inmate jailed for slashing guard’s throat with prison-issued razor
text:
Michael McKenna launched his unprovoked attack at HMP Nottingham (Picture: PA)

An inmate who fantasised about stabbing people has been jailed for 11 years for cutting a prison officer’s throat.

Michael McKenna launched his ‘unprovoked attack’ a day after arriving at troubled HMP Nottingham.

The 25-year-old had removed blades from prison-issued razors before hiding them in his fists.

He lashed out at new prison guard Michael Dye, causing a 10cm wound to his neck which required 17 stitches.

Nottingham Crown Court heard how ‘dangerous’ career criminal McKenna had 25 previous convictions for 45 offences.

Mr Dye, 23, had only been working at the jail for two months when the attack happened on April 14.

He had been unlocking the doors to the inmates’ cells to allow them their allotted hour of association.

McKenna waited on the wing after being released from his cell and yelled ‘boss’ towards the officer.

As Mr Dye turned to face the inmate, McKenna ‘lashed out’ at him – causing what the prosecution described as a ‘very significant wound’.

The attack happened in April at HM Prison Nottingham (Picture: PA)

Prosecutor Alan Murphy added: ‘The defendant said nothing and continued to swing his fists containing razor blades.’

Advertisement

Advertisement

After Mr Dye was injured, another prison officer, Alexander Malcolm, was also attacked as he came to his colleague’s aid.

The court heard Mr Malcolm had been informed of what had happened and managed to use his arm to block McKenna’s blows.

After his arrest, McKenna then racially abused a detention officer before saying: ‘Don’t touch me… or you will get what that prison officer got.’

The injured officer was taken by a colleague for treatment at the Queen’s Medical Centre in Nottingham.

He was told by medics he was fortunate there was no damage to an artery or windpipe.

The court heard that despite the attack, he plans to continue as a prison guard.

McKenna, who is currently in Wakefield Prison, pleaded guilty to inflicting grievous bodily harm on the first officer and received 11 years with an extended licence period of three years.

He also admitted attempting to inflict grievous bodily harm with intent to the second prison guard and received four-and-half years concurrently.

He further admitted a racially-aggravated offence involving the detention officer and was given nine months concurrently.

Judge Gregory Dickinson QC told him over a video link from prison to the courtroom: ‘Without warning, without reason, you lashed out with the razor – it caused a nasty gaping wound.

‘Your intent was to cause him really serious injury.’

Advertisement

Advertisement

He added: ‘It seems to me that prison officers are particularly vulnerable to attack.

‘This wasn’t just an unprovoked attack, but a pointless attack without reason.

‘There are times you fantasised about stabbing people who’d “done you wrong”.’

He referred to McKenna’s traumatic upbringing and noted there was a background of mental health issues and McKenna refused to engage with those who wished to help him.

After the hearing, Detective Constable Julian Eminson-Ferry, of Nottinghamshire Police, said: ‘McKenna is clearly a dangerous individual and this was a brutal and unprovoked attack against a prison officer who was going about his work.’
